threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_category: Device Retrieving External IP Address Detected
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET POLICY External IP Lookup ipinfo.io
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET POLICY External IP Lookup ipinfo.io"; flow:established,to_server; http.host; content:"ipinfo.io"; depth:9; endswith; fast_pattern; http.header_names; content:!"Referer"; classtype:external-ip-check; sid:2020716; rev:6; metadata:created_at 2015_03_20, updated_at 2020_09_15, reviewed_at 2024_03_27;)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the ld.so preload persistence file. See `man ld.so` for more information.
Detects the usage of utilities such as 'systemctl', 'service'...etc to stop or disable tools and services
Detects usage of the 'chattr' utility to remove immutable file attribute.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious DNS Query for IP Lookup Service APIs
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects DNS queries for IP lookup services such as "api.ipify.org" originating from a non browser process.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Network Connection to IP Lookup Service APIs
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects external IP address lookups by non-browser processes via services such as "api.ipify.org". This could be indicative of potential post compromise internet test activity.
Detects usage of base64 utility to decode arbitrary base64-encoded text
Detects usage of base64 utility to decode arbitrary base64-encoded text

attributes.magic: Bourne-Again shell script, Unicode text, UTF-8 text executable, with very long lines (4663u)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects indicators often found in linux malware samples. Note: This detection is based on common characteristics typically associated with the mentioned threats, must be considered a clue and does not conclusively prove maliciousness.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
This script performs a multi-stage attack, focusing on system compromise, persistence, evasion, and lateral movement. It begins by disabling system security features such as firewalls, SELinux, and NMI watchdog, and clearing shell history. It then attempts to remove common security monitoring agents, including those from Aliyun, Tencent Cloud, and BCM.

The script proceeds to download two archives from a remote server (`b.9-9-8.com`), which are base64-decoded and extracted into `/var/tmp/.11`. These archives contain a cryptocurrency miner (named `sshd`) and a backdoor/reverse shell (named `bioset`). It establishes persistence for the miner via a systemd service (`sshm.service`). The backdoor's systemd service (`sshb.service`) is created but not explicitly enabled in the main execution flow.

To maintain access, the script adds a hardcoded SSH public key to the root user's `authorized_keys` files and applies immutable attributes to these files. It also implements sophisticated evasion techniques:
1.  It attempts to compile and load a kernel module (rootkit) named `diamorphine.ko` to hide processes.
2.  It compiles a userland shared library that hooks `readdir`/`readdir64` to hide processes with specific names (e.g., `sshd`, `bioset`) by preloading it via `/etc/ld.so.preload`.
Additionally, it clears various system logs to remove traces of activity and cleans/locks cron job directories to prevent interference and further compromise from other sources.

For lateral movement, the script collects SSH keys, user names, hostnames, and SSH port configurations from the compromised system's files and history. It then attempts to SSH into these identified hosts using the harvested credentials. If successful, it installs a custom `vurl` utility on the remote machine and establishes cron jobs to periodically download and execute further scripts (`cronb.sh`, `t.sh`) from the attacker's server, thus propagating itself. Finally, it executes another downloaded binary (`fkoths`) and retrieves and executes an additional script (`s.sh`) from the remote server.
